etymologies: late 15th century (denoting natural science in general, especially the Aristotelian system): plural of obsolete physic ‘physical (thing’), suggested by Latin physica, Greek phusika ‘natural things’ from phusis ‘nature’

definitions: the branch of science concerned with the nature and properties of matter and energy. The subject matter of physics, distinguished from that of chemistry and biology, includes mechanics, heat, light and other radiation, sound, electricity, magnetism, and the structure of atoms.
shortDefinitions: branch of science concerned with nature and properties of matter and energy

definitions: the physical properties and phenomena of something
shortDefinitions: physical properties and phenomena of something
